seo.title: The path wrote me - Maryam Hall stopped planning and started listening

blocks.title: Inspiring Interview: Maryam Hall
blocks.subtitle: Maryam Hall stopped planning and started listening
blocks.description: When planning stops, the path begins to write itself.

professionalProfile.profession: Life Coach, Spiritual Guide, Path Transformation Counselor

areasOfFocus.areasOfImpact: Sacred Listening, Divine Guidance, Path Surrender
areasOfFocus.interviewConductedBy: Dr. Yasir Feroze (SSC), Layla Noor (SSC Fellow)

blocks.content: When all your plans fade, what do you hope remains? I hope someone remembers that their path is not just a route, but the sacred space where the Divine chooses to guide them.

blocks.title: Mystic Biography: Where Planning Became Surrender
blocks.content: Before I guided others through life transitions, I was planning my own way—not the kind that leads to clarity, but the invisible mapping of hiding from my own truth. I knew how to set goals and create strategies, but I had forgotten what it meant to listen without measuring progress or outcome.
blocks.additionalContent: I was raised in California. My father was a business consultant; my mother a spiritual teacher who whispered Rumi's poetry before dawn. It was she who gave me a copy of The Book of Surrender the day I completed my first life plan. She said, "Now learn what won't show up in your calendar."
blocks.conclusion: Dr. Kumar, whom I've never seen in person, now feels like my teacher. Sometimes I wake from dreams where I'm walking a path in Kashmir, following nothing but light.

blocks.title: The Calling – When Planning Turned Into Listening
blocks.question: Dr. Yasir Feroze, SSC: When did your coaching path transform into a spiritual calling?
blocks.answer: Oddly enough, it was during a client session about life planning. I was attempting to create a strategy when I felt something shift inside me. Most coaches would have focused on the goals, but something told me to listen deeper. As I sat with that client, I felt what I can only describe as a guidance moving through me—not my training, but something sacred.
blocks.highlightedQuote: Planning didn't teach me to control. It taught me to surrender.
blocks.additionalAnswer: That moment was my rupture. I walked out of that session a different person. I remember asking the mirror, What else have we been calling guidance that is really worship?
blocks.keyInsight: The moment when life coaching transcends strategy and becomes communion with the Divine.

blocks.title: Depth and Awakening
blocks.question: Layla Noor, SSC: What did you have to unlearn to truly guide through your coaching?
blocks.answer: That progress must always be visible. That reaching the goal was the only outcome. I had to unlearn ambition masquerading as guidance. I had to remember that stillness is also a form of movement, one conducted through the spirit.
blocks.additionalAnswer: The first time I felt this unlearning happen was during a simple meditation. I was supposed to plan my next quarter, but I found myself sitting in silence instead. I noticed how each breath moved not just efficiently, but gracefully. I began weeping. Not because I understood anything new, but because I felt something ancient. That moment taught me: not all sessions are planning, some are prayers.
blocks.secondQuestion: Dr. Yasir Feroze, SSC: When did silence first become a teacher in your guidance?
blocks.secondAnswer: I had a habit of leaving one plan unfinished each month—not from failure, but from choice. One day, I returned to find the path I'd abandoned had become clearer in my absence. No interference. Just patience.
blocks.secondAdditionalAnswer: Instead of reporting it as a failure, I made a note to myself: Perhaps paths need reverence more than planning. That single line changed the way I approached coaching. I now teach my clients: "Your silence may activate more than your strategy."
blocks.revelation: "Not all sessions are planning, some are prayers." The journey from guiding to being guided.

blocks.title: Spiritual Responsibility
blocks.question: Layla Noor, SSC: What does spiritual responsibility look like in the context of life coaching?
blocks.answer: It means never reducing people to projects. It means remembering that every life I witness, every path I guide, comes from a living being, even if transitional. Spiritual responsibility means my coaching must serve something sacred, not just something successful.
blocks.additionalAnswer: I now begin every session by writing a short personal prayer in my coaching journal: May this guidance remember its Source. That's not for validation. It's for alignment. And I share this with my clients not as doctrine, but as a choice—to remember that paths, too, were breathed into being.
blocks.secondQuestion: Dr. Yasir Feroze, SSC: How do you balance guidance and humility?
blocks.secondAnswer: By knowing that every path I witness opens a thousand new possibilities. Humility comes when I admit: I am not creating direction, I am being shown.
blocks.finalAnswer: There was a time when I was offered a position to coach the world's most successful executives in record time. I declined. Not because I wasn't capable, but because the proposal framed guidance as commodity. I realized then: some things are sacred precisely because they refuse to be rushed.

blocks.title: Legacy and Reflection – The Prayer Inside the Guidance
blocks.question: Layla Noor, SSC: When all your plans fade, what do you hope remains?
blocks.answer: I hope someone walks into a space I shaped, personally or spiritually, and feels unburdened. I hope they remember that mystery is not failure, it is fidelity to wonder.
blocks.additionalAnswer: I once watched a client cry during a simple listening exercise. Not from confusion, but because she realized, while sitting in basic silence, that she too was once just a whisper of light becoming form. That's what I want to leave behind. Not a plan, but a rhythm.
blocks.finalQuote: Let my legacy be this: that guidance, when rooted in stillness, becomes a form of worship.

blocks.title: Closing Reflection
blocks.content: When planning stops, the path begins to write itself.
